report: Diagnosis: Focally poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of mixed type with infiltration of perigastric fatty tissue, penetration of serosa, and five regional lymph node metastases. Resection margins in mucosa region are tumor-free. Tumor classification: Adenocarcinoma of mixed type, 3, pT4 N1 (5/29) LO V0 RO.

Stomach (Body) moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with metastasis in lymph nodes. The carcinoma extends from the esophagogastric junction to duodenum, measuring 8.7x6.5cm macroscopically. Perineural and angiolymphatic invasion present with moderate peritumoral desmoplasia and sparse peritumoral lymphocitary infiltrate. The surgical margins are uninvolved by neoplasia. Spleen congested, with one metastasis in the 11p lymph node and five of six lymph nodes involved by metastatic carcinoma in the 8a node. One metastasis of carcinoma is also present in the 12a lymph node. Margin uninvolved by neoplasia. Pathological staging is pT3 pN3b.

Specimen type: Total thyroidectomy
Tumor site: Left lobe
Histologic type: Papillary carcinoma
Tumor size: 1.0 CM (unifocal)
Lymph Nodes: Negative for tumor
Extent of invasion:
Primary Tumor: pT1 (size <2 cm, limited to thyroid)
Regional Lymph Nodes: pNO (No regional lymph node metastases)
Distant Metastasis: pMx (Cannot be assessed)
Margins: Uninvolved. Distance of invasive carcinoma from nearest margin: <1 mm (anterior and posterior)
Venous/Lymphatic Invasion: Absent
Additional Pathologic Findings: None identified.

Filtered Report:

Specimen type: Lobectomy. Tumor site: Lung. Tumor size: 6 x6x6cm. Histologic type: Squamous cell carcinoma. Histologic grade: Moderately differentiated. Tumor extent: Visceral pleura. Lymph nodes: 1/3 positive for metastasis (Intrathoracical 1/3).

Moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type was identified in the rectosigmoidal resection material. The tumor measured 4 cm in diameter, with circumscribed infiltration of perirectal fatty tissue and two regional lymph node metastases identified. Tumor-free colon resection margins were observed, with a minimum distance of 1 cm from the circumferential resection margin on histological section. Tumor-free mesenteric resection margin was also observed. The tumor stage was identified as pT3, pN1 (2/20) pMX, G2, L1, V0, locally R0.

The pathology report describes a surgical panel on a testicular mass. The tumor is identified as seminoma, measuring 4.9 cm in greatest dimension, and there is angiolymphatic invasion present. The tumor involves tunica albuginea and rete testis, but the surgical margins are negative for the tumor. The tumor is limited to the testis and epididymis with vascular/lymphatic invasion. There is no evidence of distant metastasis or regional lymph node involvement, making the final TNM stage pT2NXM0 and 2010 stage I. The specimen is received fresh and consists of a 46-gram testicle with attached spermatic cord. The mass extends up to but not through the tunica albuginea. The majority of the cut surfaces are pink, and there is a 1.2 x 0.8 x 0.5 cm area of orange discoloration in the head. Representative sections and additional random sections are taken for further analysis. The microscopic appearance supports the diagnosis of seminoma.

Final surgical pathology report of a female patient with lung cancer. Adenocarcinoma tumors were identified in the lower lobe of the right lung, predominantly solid type, with poorly differentiated cells and a size of 3.5 x 3.3 x 3.2 cm. No visceral pleural invasion was identified, and there was no definite vascular invasion. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in one of two lymph nodes. One of the tumors was acinar predominant and well differentiated with a size of 1mm. Three intraparenchymal lymph nodes were negative for carcinoma. The bronchial and vascular margin status were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia and acute bronchopneumonia were identified in the lungs. The tumors in part A and C are likely separate primary tumors. TNM descriptors indicate multiple primary tumors. No treatment effect was identified.

Filtered report: A poorly differentiated, partially mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type was found in a right hemicolectomy preparation. The tumor is located 0.5 cm aborally to Bauhin's valve and encircling the intestinal wall at a length of 5 cm, with invasive spreading within all intestinal wall layers to the subserosa. Three of nineteen lymph nodes display metastasis, not extending across the capsules. Stage of tumor is therefore: pT3, pN1 (3/19) LO V0; G3 R0.

Pathological diagnosis: Brain biopsy, right parieto-occipital lobe revealing Oligodendroglioma (grade B) with a MIB-1 index of 6%. Gross pathology: A 1.2 x 0.6 cm tissue fragment with focally hemorrhagic, gray-white soft brain parenchyma 1.5 x 1.2 x 1 cm in aggregate was observed. Microscopic analysis revealed a hypercellular oligodendroglioma involving both the cortex and the white matter, with areas of prominent nuclear pleomorphism and hyperchromasia, clusters of calcification, and focal areas of endothelial hyperplasia. No necrosis was identified. Tissue committee code: TC1. Clinical history and pre-op Dx were not provided.

The pathology report describes a brain tumor in a female patient. The tumor is identified as a gemistocytic type astrocytoma, WHO grade II, with some regions showing characteristics of a grade III astrocytoma but with a low MIB-1 index. The report includes gross descriptions of three parts of the tumor received for frozen section and permanent sections. The sections confirm the presence of a low-grade glioma in the brain tissue. Multiple soft white-red fragments of tissue with different dimensions are entirely submitted for analysis. Representative sections are also submitted for the specimen's soft pale tan-red nodules. All sections are fixed in 20% formalin overnight for further analysis. The report does not provide any information regarding the patient's treatment plan or sample size, shape, or weight.

The pathology report describes an en bloc resection specimen consisting of the terminal ileum, right colon, transverse colon, greater curvature of the stomach, mid-jejunum, and abdominal wall. The invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma is present in the terminal ileum, right colon, transverse colon, omentum, mid-jejunum, greater curvature of the stomach, and abdominal wall. The invasive carcinoma is 4.5 x 4.5 cm while focal squamous differentiation is also present. The lymph nodes (25) are negative for cancer. The gastric mucosa has focal chronic gastritis while the margins are negative for carcinoma. The excision of the gastric suture line reveals no tumor. The tumor site is the transverse colon, which has an infiltrative and ulcerating configuration. The tumor size is 4.5 x 4.5 cm, and it is classified as adenocarcinoma with a histologic grade of G3. The margins are deemed negative for carcinoma while lymphovascular and perineural invasion are not noted. Other pathologic findings include abscess formation and dense adhesions. The extent of resection is R0, and the pathologic stage is pT4 NO Mx. Multiple lymph nodes that are grossly negative for tumor are seen, and a representative section of various tissues is submitted for examination.

The pathology report describes the results of five brain biopsies from one patient. Four biopsies show infiltrating malignant gliomas with features of anaplasia, including prominent nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic figures, and occasional individual cell necrosis. These tumors also have gemistocytic astrocytoma and anaplastic oligodendroglioma features. Only one biopsy shows atypical glial proliferation. The MIB-1 index is 2%, and there are no areas of necrosis or vascular endothelial proliferation observed. The neoplasms are classified as grade III/IV. Immunoperoxidase staining for GFAP demonstrates macro and mini gemistocytic phenotypes of tumor cells.

The patient underwent laparoscopic abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, bilateral pelvic and para-aortic lymph node dissection, and pelvic biopsies due to endometrial cancer. Molecular testing identified loss of heterozygosity in both endometrial and ovarian tumors. The uterine tumor was moderately differentiated endometroid adenocarcinoma with involvement of anterior and posterior endomyometrium, endocervical glands, and cervical stroma. Complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia and adenomyosis were also present. Lymph nodes were negative for cancer. The ovarian tumor was moderately differentiated endometroid carcinoma with marked cytoplasmic atypia and a ruptured tumor capsule. No positive lymph nodes were found. The ovarian tumor was staged as pT2c and FIGO stage IIC.

The pathology report describes a case of a right lung mass where a pneumonectomy has been performed. The specimen received is labeled "right lung" and weighs 757 grams, with nodules present on the lung, pleura, and pulmonary vasculature. Microscopic examination indicates adenocarcinoma extending into the middle lobe. The tumor is moderately differentiated and has invaded the visceral pleura and lymphovascular spaces. Metastatic carcinoma is present in 5 out of 10 lymph nodes examined. A limited panel of immunohistochemical stains is positive for TTF1 and CK7 and negative for CK20, supporting the diagnosis of primary lung malignancy. The report mentions that the test performed by the laboratory is used for clinical purposes and the laboratory is certified under the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments.

The pathology report describes the excisions made during the left tonsil tumor resection procedure in a  patient. The specimen includes several tissue samples labeled and submitted in formalin. The report indicates the presence of lymph nodes and detailed information on the size and characteristics of squamous cell carcinoma, including foci of angiolymphatic and perineural space invasion, invasion of underlying skeletal muscle, very focal invasion of minor salivary gland tissue, and no apparent gross bony invasion. According to the report, there is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the soft tissue, designated left level III excision. Lymph nodes designated as left neck dissection (level II and III) show metastatic carcinoma in only one of the 26 lymph nodes and no evidence of extracapsular soft tissue extension. Furthermore, there is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in 4 lymph nodes designated left, level IA excision or level V, excision, which contains 5 lymph nodes. The overall diagnosis is invasive squamous cell carcinoma with a size of 3.5 cm and moderately differentiated. The report suggests the inked surgical margins are free of carcinoma. However, there are foci that approximate the margins, which are interpreted as tissue tear-distortion with ink run-off, and not free margins. Pending decalcification, assessment of bony invasion and bony margins will lead to the reporting of the results as an addendum.
Histology and morphology are consistent with anaplastic astrocytoma WHO grade III. Diagnosis is anaplastic astrocytoma WHO grade III.

The report describes a radical resection of a pleomorphic undifferentiated sarcoma located on the left back. The tumor involves the deep, superior, and inferior resection margins and has a size of 5.0 cm. The mitotic rate is 12/10 high-power fields (HPF), and there is necrosis present. Two additional margins were excised, and no tumor is identified in either. The specimen is inked for orientation and representative sections are submitted for analysis. There are no other lesions identified. Microscopic examination was performed.

The pathology report includes five specimens: a portion of the 6th right rib, a biopsy of the middle lobe peribronchial lymph node, a right lower lobe, an excisional biopsy of lymph node #8, and an excisional biopsy of lymph node #4. Frozen section diagnosis revealed that FS2 was negative for metastatic disease, while FS3A and FS3B indicated a poorly differentiated non-small-cell carcinoma from the right lower lobe. The gross description for specimen 3 revealed a well-circumscribed solid tumor mass occupying a subhilar position within the central portion of the lobe. The specimens were submitted for diagnosis, and the report shows anthracosis and metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in lymph node #8. There was no evidence of tumor in lymph node #4. The report indicates that there is a transition from benign to neoplastic squamous epithelium and notable invasion seen in specimen #3I. The remainder of lung parenchyma shows congestion with no evidence of pneumonic process.

Specimen type: Excision of tumor. Tumor site: Skin, trunk. Tumor size: 2.8x2x0.4cm. Histologic type: Nodular melanoma. Additional findings: Tumor is multcentric, 4th level of invasion in bigger nodule, 2 level of. invasion in smaller nodule. Comments: Breslow thickness 4.0mm.
Cervical biopsy reveals histological grade 2 invasive squamous cell carcinoma.

The pathology report describes the results of a radical cystectomy with ileal conduit due to metastatic urothelial carcinoma. The tissue samples taken from the urinary bladder show invasive, moderately to poorly differentiated papillary urothelial carcinoma, which has spread to the entire thickness of the bladder wall and involves the seminal vesicles, vasa deferentia, and rectum. The distal resection margin of the rectum is involved by the tumor, while the proximal resection margin is free of tumor. There is extensive perineural and lymphovascular space invasion. Bilateral ureteral mucosa show mild to severe atypia. The prostate is unremarkable. Multiple lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma. The pathology stage is pT4a, N2 (5/93), M1.

The pathology report includes findings for the right and left pelvic lymph nodes and the prostate and seminal vesicles. The right and left pelvic lymph nodes each have two lymph nodes, and no tumors are present. The prostate and seminal vesicles have been diagnosed with prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 7 (3+4), and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN). The tumor focus measures 2.5 x 1.5 cm in the largest cross-sectional dimension and is confined to the prostate, with margins of resection free of tumor. The seminal vesicles and segments of vasa deferentia are grossly free of tumor. The report includes gross descriptions and section codes of the lymph nodes and prostate and seminal vesicles, and SNOMED codes are also listed.

The report describes a radical prostatectomy and bilateral pelvic lymph node dissection performed on a patient with a PSA value of 7.7 ng/ml and a history of prostatic adenocarcinoma. The final diagnosis includes adenocarcinoma involving both lobes of the prostate with a greatest histologic nodular diameter of 2.1 cm and extraprostatic extension present in the right posterior apex and posterior mid prostate. Extensive perineural invasion is identified, but no angiolymphatic invasion is present. All examined surgical resection margins are free of neoplasia, while the bilateral seminal vesicles and distal vasa deferentia are benign. The histologic grade is G3-4, and tertiary Gleason pattern 5 carcinoma component is present. Multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is identified, with a TNM pathologic stage of pT3a NO MX. No evidence of neoplasia is found in lymph node excisions.

The pathology report includes information regarding various specimens collected during surgery, including biopsies of both ureters (which were negative for malignancy) and the bladder. The bladder specimen showed the presence of a urothelial carcinoma with focal squamous differentiation, as well as the presence of high-grade urothelial dysplasia/flat carcinoma in situ. The report also indicates lymphovascular space invasion and metastatic urothelial carcinoma found in a lymph node. The prostate gland specimen showed the presence of adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 6/10 and involvement of the prostatic apex margin but no lymph node involvement. The report confirms the diagnosis of the identified malignancies and provides relevant information for clinical evaluation and treatment planning.

The patient is a female with metastatic high-grade adenocarcinoma. The omentum and uterus are extensively infiltrated by the tumor. Histologic typing and grading reveal a serous carcinoma of endometrial origin. The tumor focally extends 0.3 cm into a 1.1 cm thick myometrium. Lymphovascular space invasion is not definitively identified, and surgical margin status is not definitive. The lymph node status indicates no lymph nodes were removed. The specimen received includes a portion of the omentum, omentum, and uterus with the right tube and ovary. The gross description indicates two gray-white tumor nodules ranging from 2.0 to 6.0 cm in the omentum. The uterus is 5.6 cm in length, and the right ovary measures 3.0 x 1.5 x 1.3 cm. The specimen is submitted for permanent sections. The frozen section diagnosis confirms metastatic adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemical stains for WT-1 and P53 show positive staining for P53 with no to only focal nuclear staining for WT1. The diagnosis is pT3a NX (FIGO IIIA).

Final diagnosis: Invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated in the bile duct, pancreas, and duodenum (Whipple procedure). Additional pancreatic margin excision showed low-grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia but no evidence of carcinoma or high-grade dysplasia. No distant metastasis detected. The tumor invades adjacent structures/organs (duodenum) and regional lymph nodes (pN1b). Margins are free of tumor with 1 mm distance of invasive carcinoma from the closest margin (retroperitoneal margin) and no venous invasion (V) but with both lymphatic invasion (L) and perineural invasion. Grossly, the specimen consists of resected portions of the pancreatic head and attached duodenum with a palpable pancreatic mass. The pancreatic duct is totally occluded by the presence of the tumor, which abuts the retroperitoneal surface/uncinate process, involves the common bile duct and the duodenal wall, and grossly involves the ampulla of Vater. Two moderate-sized lymph nodes with no grossly uninvolved pancreatic tissue are isolated. A representative section of the tumor is submitted to the Tissue Procurement Laboratory.

A left renal mass and surrounding tissue were biopsied, and the left kidney was found to have a partial-nephrectomy. The tumor was identified as renal cell carcinoma - Conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade III/IV and a greatest diameter of 3.0 cm. No local invasion, renal vein invasion, or small vessel angiolymphatic invasion was identified, and the surgical margins were free of tumor. The non-neoplastic kidney showed mild arteriosclerotic changes, and no adrenal gland or lymph node involvement was identified. Additionally, benign samples of the left renal margin, left 11th rib, soft tissue left peri-nephric area, soft tissue over the tumor in the left kidney, and left hilar lymph node were biopsied. Intraoperative consultations confirmed the frozen section diagnosis of renal cortical tumor with a favorable prognosis for conventional renal cell carcinoma and negative margins. The permanent diagnosis remained the same for all biopsy samples.

Patient presented with a renal mass and underwent left partial nephrectomy. Pathology report reveals a renal cell carcinoma of conventional (clear cell) type with a Fuhrman Nuclear Grade of III/IV. Tumor size is 4.2 cm and there is local invasion beyond renal capsule but confined within Gerota's fascia. No renal vein invasion or small vessel angiolymphatic invasion is identified. Surgical margin is free of the tumor. Non-neoplastic kidney shows a benign cortical cyst. Adrenal gland and lymph nodes are not identified. The frozen section diagnosis shows renal cortical neoplasm with a negative margin, which is confirmed in the permanent diagnosis.

Filtered Pathology Report: 

Final Diagnosis: Left kidney: Renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type. Tumor site: Lateral aspect of the lower pole extending into the central portion of the kidney. Tumor size: 6.9 x 5.5 X 5.3 cm. Nuclear grade: Fuhrman grade 2/4. Lymphovascular space invasion: No. Transcapsular invasion: Yes. Renal vein invasion: No. Vena caval invasion: Not resected. Adrenal gland: Benign adrenal gland tissue without evidence of metastatic disease. Surgical margin status: Soft tissue margins Negative. Ureteral margin: Negative. Vascular margins: Negative. Other: Chronic pyelonephritis. The test has been finalized at the Campus. #.

A 3 cm exophytic left renal mass was diagnosed as conventional (clear cell) type renal cell carcinoma. Another papillary type renal cell carcinoma was also detected. The clear cell carcinoma had a nuclear grade of II/IV and was 2.2 cm in size, while the papillary tumor was type 1 and measured 1.1 cm. Local invasion was not identified, renal vein invasion was not detected and surgical margins were free of tumor. A few non-neoplastic minute papillary tubular adenomas were present. Adrenal gland and lymph nodes were not identified. The staging for renal cell carcinoma/oncocytoma was pT1 with a tumor size <= 7.0 cm in greatest dimension limited to the kidney. The left kidney was partially nephrectomized. Tumor number one was well-circumscribed and grossly located 0.2 cm from the resection margin, while tumor number two was friable, necrotic and located 0.3 cm from the resection margin. The renal capsule was not involved. Intraoperative consultation showed negative margins for both tumors, which was confirmed as permanent diagnosis.

Patient History: Right renal mass. 

Specimens Submitted: 
1. SP: Kidney, right, partial nephrectomy.
2. SP: Kidney, right, biopsy. 

Diagnosis: 
1. SP: Kidney, right, partial nephrectomy: Renal cell carcinoma - Conventional (clear cell) type with Fuhrman Nuclear Grade III/IV. Tumor size is 3.3 cm in greatest diameter, with no local or renal vein invasion and surgical margins free of tumor. Non-neoplastic kidney is unremarkable. 
2. SP: Kidney, right, biopsy: Mild Diabetic Nephropathy with focal segmental and global glomerulosclerosis, tubular atrophy, and mild interstitial fibrosis. No other specific glomerular lesions identified.

Intraoperative consultation: Renal cortical neoplasm with the margin appearing free on one representative section. Permanent diagnosis: same.

A total nephrectomy of the left kidney was performed due to a renal cell carcinoma - conventional (clear cell) type with focal sercomatoid features of nuclear grade IV/IV. The tumor measured 5.6 cm in diameter and showed no local invasion or renal vein invasion. The surgical margins were free of tumor, and non-neoplastic kidney tissue showed benign cortical cysts, papillary edenomas, and mild arteriosclerotic changes. The adrenal gland and lymph nodes were not identified. The perinephric fat showed benign fibroadipose tissue. Intraoperative consultation confirmed the diagnosis of renal cortical carcinoma, which was confirmed by permanent sections.

Clinical Diagnosis & History: Right renal mass. Specimens Submitted: 1. Kidney, right upper pole, partial nephrectomy. DIAGNOSIS: 1. Kidney, right upper pole, partial nephrectomy: Tumor Type: Renal cell carcinoma - Conventional (clear cell) type. Fuhrman Nuclear Grade: Nuclear grade II/IV. Tumor Size: Greatest diameter is 3.5 cm. Local Invasion (for renal cortical types): Not identified. Renal Vein Invasion: Not identified. Surgical Margins: Free of tumor. Non-Neoplastic Kidney: Focal chronic inflammation and vascular sclerosis. Adrenal Gland: Not identified. Lymph Nodes: Not identified. Staging for renal cell carcinoma/oncocytoma: pT1 Tumor <= 7.0 cm In greatest dimension limited to the kidney. I ATTEST THAT THE ABOVE DIAGNOSIS IS BASED UPON MY PERSONAL EXAMINATION OF THE SLIDES (AND/OR OTHER MATERIAL), AND THAT I HAVE REVIEWED AND APPROVED THIS REPORT. Gross Description: 1). The specimen is received fresh labeled "Right upper pole partial nephrectomy". It consists of a 50 g, 4.5 x 4.5 x 3.5 cm portion of renal parenchyma with attached fat measuring 7.1 x 3.8 x 2.2 cm. The resected margin of the specimen is inked black. The specimen is sectioned to reveal a 3.5 x 3.2 x 2.5 cm well-circumscribed hemorrhagic mass which is located 0.5 cm from the closest resected margin. The mass abuts the renal capsule but does not grossly involve it. The remainder of the renal parenchyma is brown-tan and grossly unremarkable. Representative sections are submitted. A sample of the tumor is given to TPS. Summary of sections: TM - tumor with margin. TC - tumor with renal capsule. RS - representative section of uninvolved kidney. TN - tumor with normal kidney. Summary of Sections: Part 1: Kidney, right upper pole, partial nephrectomy. Block. Sect. Site. PCs. 1. fsc. 1. rs. 1. 1. to. 1. 2. tm. 2.

Clinical Diagnosis & History: Right renal mass s/p IR biopsy that demonstrated high grade, renal cell carcinoma.
Specimens Submitted: 1: MESENTARY, OVERLYING RIGHT RENAL TUMOR; BIOPSY. 2: GEROTA'S FASCIA, ANTERIOR; BIOPSY. 3: KIDNEY. LOWER POLE AND CAVAL LYMPH NODES, PARTIAL NEPHRECTOMY.
Diagnosis: 1. MESENTARY, OVERLYING RIGHT RENAL TUMOR; BIOPSY: -Benign fibrofatty tissue. 2. GEROTA'S FASCIA, ANTERIOR; BIOPSY: -Benign fibrofatty tissue. 3. KIDNEY, LOWER POLE AND CAVAL LYMPH NODES, PARTIAL NEPHRECTOMY: Tumor Type: Renal coll carcinoma - Unclassified type. High grade. Tumor Size: Greatest diameter is 4.2 cm. Local Invasion (for renal cortical types): Involves renal sinus fat. Renal Vein Invasion: Not identified. Surgical Margins: Tumor present at renal parenchymal margin (for partial nephrectomy specimens only). Non-Neoplastic Kidney: Chronic nephritis, mild arteriolonephrosclerosis. Adrenal Gland: Not identified. Lymph Nodes: Number of metastatic nodes: 3. Number of nodes examined: 8. Staging for renal cell carcinoma: pT3 Tumor extends into major veins or invades the adrenal gland or perinephric tissue but not beyond Gerota's fascia. Comment: High grade tumor has features seen in both distal nephron (collecting duct) and "type 2" papillary renal carcinoma.
Special Studies: Special Stain. Comment. PAS. 34BE 12. CK7. RACEMASE. CEA M. IMM RECUT. NEG CONT. RECUT.
Intraoperative Consultation: Note: The diagnoses given in this section pertain only to the tissue sample examined at the time of the intraoperative consultation. 1). FROZEN SECTION DIAGN/ cD. MESENTERY OVERLYING RIGHT ANTERIOR KIDNEY TUMORI. BENIGN FIBROUS TISSUE. PERMANENT DIAGNOSIS: SAME. 2). FROZEN SECTION DIAGNOSIS: SP: ANTERIOR GEROTA FASCIA. PERMANENT DIAGNOSIS: SAME.

The pathology report indicates that the patient has invasive ductal carcinoma in two separate foci in the left breast, measuring 3.5 and 2.5 cm in greatest dimension, with margins of resection free of carcinoma. The report also notes metastatic carcinoma present in two of four sentinel lymph nodes and axillary lymph nodes. The report includes details on the histologic type, glandular/tubular differentiation, nuclear grade, mitotic count, and overall grade of the invasive carcinoma. The report also notes the absence of lobular carcinoma in situ and the presence of extensive intraductal component. Additional findings include intraductal papillomas and proliferative fibrocystic changes. The report provides results of immunohistochemical studies and dual in situ hybridization testing for HER2 gene amplification status. No additional information is included.

The pathology report describes a patient who underwent a right segmental mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy. The final diagnosis reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma and separate foci of ductal carcinoma in situ. The carcinoma is poorly differentiated with a Nottingham score of 9/9. Lymphovascular invasion is identified, and the ductal carcinoma in situ extends close to the posterior surgical margin of resection. All surgical margins of resection are free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic breast has fibrocytic changes. The sentinel lymph nodes and non-sentinel lymph node biopsy are negative for tumor. The report also includes an estrogen/progesterone and HER-2/neu assay. The DAKO HERCEPTEST reveals a weak to moderate complete membrane staining in over 10% of the tumor cells, interpreted as weakly positive with a score of 2+. A confirmation test for Her2/neu will be subsequently reported. Cytokeratin (AE1/3) stains have been performed to confirm the negative status of the sentinel lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes a left breast mastectomy specimen with invasive mammary carcinoma, micropapillary type, poorly differentiated and Nottingham Grade 3 present in 13/14 slides. Ductal carcinoma in situ is also present with a high nuclear grade (DIN3) as a single focus. Metastatic carcinoma is present in five out of five intra mammary lymph nodes, seventeen out of twenty axillary lymph nodes, two out of two lymph nodes in level 3 of the left lymph node dissection, and five out of five lymph nodes in the lymph node dissection above the left brachial plexus. Lymphovascular invasion is also present. The tumor is ER and PR positive and HER2 negative. The report does not include any information on the patient's identifying details, treatment plan, sample size, and weight.

The pathology report describes a specimen consisting of right axillary sentinel nodes and a right breast mass. The lymph nodes were negative for malignancy on routine and immunohistochemical stains. The breast mass was a mixed epithelial/mesenchymal metaplastic carcinoma (carcinosarcoma) with a malignant sarcomatous component, histologic grade 3, poorly differentiated, and sized 2.5 cm. The margins were negative, and lymph nodes were examined in parts A and B, which were negative for malignancy. The breast specimen also had ductal carcinoma in situ, high nuclear grade with central necrosis, and multifocal tumors with three foci. The largest, most dominant mass was considered for staging, grade, and scoring. The ER and PR were weakly positive, whereas Her-2 neu was negative. Three lymph nodes were sampled, all negative for metastasis. The gross description of the specimen and its sectioning into multiple cassettes with different stains for each cassette was detailed.

Pathology report summary: The left breast segmental biopsy identified invasive ductal carcinoma with micro papillary features and ductal carcinoma in-situ. The tumor measured 2.1 x 1.8 x 1.3 cm with about 10% of micro papillary carcinoma. No prominent angiolymphatic invasion was observed. The margins were free of invasive and in situ carcinoma, but the closest margin was 1mm from the tumor. Fibrocystic changes with ductal epithelial hyperplasia were identified, and microcalcifications were observed in benign epithelium and arterial wall. The axillary dissection contents revealed metastatic tumor in one of the seventeen lymph nodes. The metastatic carcinoma measured 1.2x0.8 cm with extracapsular spread. The estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor were positive, while HER-2/neu was negative.

A 1-year-old female presented with a right breast mass and core biopsy showing invasive ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated. The patient underwent total mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsies. Histological examination revealed invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 3.1 cm with ductal carcinoma in situ also identified, constituting <= 25% of the total tumor mass. The invasive carcinoma is located in the upper outer quadrant, and no involvement of the nipple or skin is identified. Biopsy site changes and fibrocystic changes with apocrine metaplasia, microcalcifications, and columnar cell alteration without atypia are observed in the non-neoplastic breast tissue. Benign lymph nodes are identified in sentinel node biopsies, with additional sections ordered for deeper recuts and special stains. The results of special stains for ER, PR, and HER2/neu are positive, negative, and negative, respectively. Microscopic clusters of metastatic carcinoma measuring less than 2mm are identified in one sentinel lymph node. Intraoperative consultation confirmed all lymph nodes as benign.

Diagnosis: Invasive ductal carcinoma with poorly differentiated intermediate nuclear grade, massive vascular permeation including nipple, and fibrocystic changes. Three out of fifteen axillary lymph nodes positive for metastatic tumor with capsular and extracapsular extension. Previous reports indicate left mastectomy due to neiltrating ductal carcinoma, not otherwise specified.

The pathology report is for a patient with invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) on core biopsy of the left breast. There were 10 specimens submitted for examination, including three sentinel lymph nodes in the left axilla. Sentinel node #1 contained a microscopic cluster of tumor cells (<0.2mm) within a capsular lymphatic vessel, while sentinel nodes #2 and #3 were benign. The left breast mass was found to contain invasive ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated with histologic grade III/III, measuring 1.9 cm, and focal ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The DCIS constituted less than 25% of the total tumor mass and was present admixed with and adjacent to the invasive carcinoma. The HER2/neu gene amplification was not detected. All identified lymph nodes and tumor tissue were submitted for examination.

The pathology report describes a left breast biopsy in a patient with invasive ductal carcinoma and associated lymphocytic infiltrate. The largest focus of invasive carcinoma is 1.2 cm in the greatest dimension in the medial aspect of the specimen, with multiple satellite foci. Ductal carcinoma in situ extends over a 4 cm area, approaching the final inferior margin. Metastatic carcinoma is identified in one of thirty lymph nodes. The report includes gross descriptions and serial sections submitted for various tissue samples. Immunohistochemistry results show negative estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative HER-2/neu overexpression. The HER-2/neu gene levels are evaluated by FISH and demonstrate no amplification.

Summary: There is a skin lesion measuring 8x4 cm with a pigmented mass measuring 2x1.5 cm invading into the fatty tissue. Microscopic examination of the lesion shows malignant melanoma with ulceration, Clark's level IV, and a Breslow depth of 15 mm. The tumor is uninvolved at the margins and there is no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion. The histologic grade is undifferentiated and no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment is present.

SUMMARY:

A skin biopsy labeled as "right chest, Skin melanoma" was received for examination, measuring 6 x 3 x 0.7 cm. The lesion was identified as a malignant melanoma, nodular type, with a Clark level IV and 6mm in depth. Mitotic index was observed at 1/ mmÂ², lymph-vascular invasion was not identified, tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes were present, and ulceration was identified. The margins of the specimen were free of tumor. Additionally, two sentinel lymph nodes labeled as right axillary sentinel lymph node #1 and left axillary sentinel lymph node #2 were received for examination, and both were negative for metastasis. Immunoperoxidase stains for HMB45 and S-100 were done and reported as negative. Pathologic staging was indicated as pT4b pNo pMx.

The report describes the case of a male patient who underwent a total thyroidectomy due to the presence of multiple thyroid tumors. The tumors were primarily located on the right lobe and isthmus, and the largest tumor measured at 3.1 cm x 1.5 cm x 1.1 cm. One of the tumors was identified as a papillary carcinoma with a follicular variant, accounting for less than 99% of the tumor. The tumors did not invade the surrounding tissues, lymphovascular spaces, or nerves. The histologic grade of the tumor was well differentiated, and its capsule remained intact. The surgical margin of the specimen was uninvolved by carcinoma, and the closest margin had a distance of less than 1 mm from the invasive carcinoma. No malignant cells were observed in the right inferior parathyroid gland that was also resected during surgery. The PTNM stage was pT2NX.

Histopathological examination was conducted on a total organ resection of the left breast. The clinical diagnosis was bifocal cancer of the left breast, and a simple mastectomy was performed. Results of the immunohistochemical examination showed estrogen receptors in over 75% of neoplastic cell nuclei, progesterone receptors in 10-75% of neoplastic cell nuclei, and HER2 protein stained negatively in invasive cancerous cells. Macroscopic description revealed Carcinoma ductale bifocale - NHG2. Carcinoma ductale in situ (DCIS) was observed in the tumors. There was also an invasion of carcinomatosa vasorum and in situ lesion of the type cancerisatio lobulorum. The histopathological diagnosis is invasive bifocal ductal carcinoma and carcinoma in situ of the left breast (NHG2, pTic, pNO (SN)), with vascular invasion. Compliance is valid.

The pathology report indicates the presence of papillary thyroid carcinoma in a total thyroidectomy specimen. There were three foci of carcinoma in the left lobe, with the largest being 1.0 cm and exhibiting extrathyroidal extension but with clear margins. The tumor was classified as pT3 NO with no lymphatic invasion and with two lymph nodes examined and no tumor present. There was also nodular goiter identified. The report states that all tissue was submitted for histologic evaluation.

The report is for a patient with endometrial cancer who underwent TAH-BSO with staging. The specimens received include right gutter implant, uterus, cervix, tubes and ovaries, left pelvic lymph node, left aortic lymph node, right pelvic lymph node, and right caval lymph node. The report indicates Endosalpingiosis with no tumor present in the right gutter implant, but the uterus, cervix, tubes, and ovaries showed endometrial adenocarcinoma with histologic grade 3 and nuclear grade 3. The tumor size is 6.0 cm, and the extent of invasion is less than 50% with no lympho/vascular invasion. The serosa and parametrium are free of tumors, but cervical involvement appears present. The left, right pelvic, and right caval lymph nodes all showed no metastasis, while one lymph node from the left aortic lymph node was negative for metastasis. Adenomyosis was also noted, and the special studies were performed on request. The microscopic findings supported the abovementioned diagnosis.

Summary:

The pathology report describes a tumor in the liver that is solid, ill-defined, gray-white, and measures 5x4x4cm. The tumor cells form patterns such as trabecular, cords, tubules, and adenoids, with abundant cytoplasm that is clear or basophilic, irregularly large and hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli, and the presence of mitoses. The tumor invades into the fibrous stroma and is marked by invasion of inflammatory cells and necrosis. The diagnosis is hepatocellular carcinoma and cholangiocarcinoma, combined, with moderately differentiated histologic grade. The report provides no additional pathological findings or comments.

Liver biopsy results show the presence of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma in two segments (I and VIII) without any significant necrosis or invasion. Both lesions have diameters of 1.2 cm and 1.7 cm, exhibiting solid, trabecular, and focally pseudoacinar morphological patterns. The adjacent hepatic parenchyma has mild lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate, baloniforme degeneration in 30% of hepatocytes, and severe fibrosis, indicating B virus infection. The lesions are free from neoplastic infiltration in surgical margins. The pathological staging is pT2 pNx. No significant hemosiderosis is observed.

The pathology report describes the specimens received for analysis, including two lymph nodes from the left axilla, a left breast mass with needle localization, and an additional margin from the left breast. The left breast mass specimen is further described as a 1.5cm invasive, lobular carcinoma with a grade 2 SBR, located in the upper inner quadrant. The surgical margins are negative for tumor. The report also includes synoptic reports for ER/PR results and HER2 results, indicating positivity for estrogen and progesterone receptors and equivocal HER2 amplification. The report mentions an attempt to conduct FISH for HER2 amplification, but the tissue did not remain on the slide for analysis. The final diagnosis indicates negative results for metastases in both lymph nodes. Overall, the report provides details on the size, location, and type of cancer present in the left breast, as well as information on the status of lymph nodes and hormone receptors.

The pathology report concerns a 600-gram excisional biopsy specimen of a left breast cancer, including an axilla, two ellipses of skin, and a nipple with areola. Histological analysis reveals multifocal invasive carcinoma, measuring 2.8 x 2.5 x 1.6 cm in the upper-outer quadrant and 1 cm in the lower-inner quadrant, with a high histologic and nuclear grade of 3 of 3. Ductal, solid in-situ carcinoma with minimal cribiform and necrosis is also present. The surgical margins, nipple, and skin are free of tumor, and 17 lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy. Estrogen and progesterone receptor analysis indicates positive nuclear estrogen receptor expression and borderline progesterone receptor expression, while HER2/neu immunohistochemical analysis indicates that the tumor cells do not overexpress HER2/neu oncoprotein. Proliferation index is judged to be high. No further information on treatment plan or patient outcomes is provided.

The pathology report describes a right hemicolectomy specimen with an ulcerated cecal carcinoma. The histological type of the carcinoma is a moderately differentiated, partially mucus-forming colorectal adenocarcinoma, which measures 5.5 cm in its largest diameter and subtotally encloses the cecum. Invasive tumor spread is observed into all intestinal wall layers as far as the mesocolic fatty tissue and subserosa. Colon mucosa is observed with some tubular adenomas with moderate epithelial dysplasia. The oral and aboral resection margins and greater omentum are tumor-free. Four out of twenty-nine regional lymph nodes are observed with metastases from the colon carcinoma. The tumor stage is determined to be pT3, pN2 (4/29), and G2.

This pathology report pertains to a sample of renal and ureter tissue from a patient with renal cell carcinoma, papillary type. The tumor is 6 cm in size and histology reveals it to be of grade/differentiation IV. Pathological T is T1b and pathological N is NX. Clinical M is M0. There are no additional histology comments. Additionally, there is mention of a sample type BUFFY but no further information is provided.

A pathology report is provided for four specimens labeled A to D. The clinical history shows invasive bladder cancer and the post-operative diagnosis is confirmed as bladder cancer. Intraoperative consultation of the two ureter specimens, A and B show negative for malignancy. The final pathologic diagnosis of ureters A and B show negative for malignancy. The specimen from the bladder and prostate labeled C, shows a high-grade infiltrating urothelial carcinoma, and adenocarcinoma of the prostate with both lobes having 10% tumor involvement. Margins of resection are free of tumor. The vermiform appendix specimen labeled D appears normal. The report states that additional tests were performed and referred. No information is provided about the patient, doctor, hospital, or treatment plan. The summary report is based on the clinical information, the intraoperative consultation, final pathologic diagnosis, and gross description of each specimen.

A 110-year-old female patient presented with a 5.5 cm right breast mass. The pathology report reveals a multicentric invasive lobular carcinoma measured 5.5 cm, with lobular carcinoma in situ identified. No calcifications are found, but perineural invasion is present, and invasive carcinoma extends to the cauterized anterior flap margin. The skin is involved by invasive carcinoma, and the lymph node status is negative. Immunohistochemical tests show ER: 85Z nuclear staining with moderate intensity, PR: 408 nuclear staining with moderate intensity, and HER2/neu (HERCEPTEST): negative. The tumor stage is T3, PNO (I+), MX. The report includes a detailed gross description of the surgical specimen.

The pathology report describes two masses, one in segment 3 and the other in segment 7 of the liver, both identified as hepatocellular carcinoma. The report indicates that the tumor in segment 3 measures 3.5 x 2.5 x 2.5 cm and is well-demarcated and lobulated with multinodular confluent gross type. The tumor in segment 7 measures 0.9 x 0.8 x 0.8 cm and is well-demarcated with a homogenous pale tan and solid mass with multinodular confluent gross type. The report states that there is no involvement of the resection margin for either mass. The remaining liver parenchyme is identified as cirrhosis with mixed steatosis, mild. Other details such as patient and treatment information, as well as irrelevant findings in other parts of the body, were excluded.

The pathology report describes the surgical specimen of a total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and omentectomy. The uterus contains a polypoid mass composed of a FIGO grade 3 endometrial adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation invading 0.6 cm into the myometrium. However, the cervix and serosal surface are not involved, and the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are negative for tumor. No tumor is found in the omentum, lymph nodes, gonadal vessels, and staging biopsies of various pelvic organs. An appendix is also unremarkable. The preliminary consultation confirms endometrial carcinoma, endometrioid type with focal clear cell features and extensive squamous differentiation, and recommends holding over for confirmation on permanent sections.

The pathology report concerns a case of retroperitoneal mass in the left kidney and adrenal gland, likely sarcoma. The patient underwent radical resection, nephrectomy, and adrenalectomy, which resulted in the identification of a dedifferentiated liposarcoma with a highly malignant spindle cell sarcoma component, a well-differentiated liposarcoma component, and a background of lipoma-like and sclerosing type. The tumor measured 21cm. The spleen was also removed and weighed 152g, with no significant pathological changes. The report provides detailed gross descriptions of the specimens, including ureter measurements, arterial margins, adrenal gland measurements, and multiple masses with different surfaces and colors. Representative sections of the mass were submitted for TPS and culture, while photographs were also taken. The summary of sections shows that there were sections of adipose tissue around the kidney, normal kidney tissue, well-differentiated, myxoid areas, poorly differentiated areas, and margins. The summary also shows that the splenic capsule was gray-tan, nodular, and glistening, with a hemorrhagic and disrupted hilar area containing areas of blood clot.

A pathology report was conducted on the patient's soft tissue, pelvic and periaortic lymph nodes, uterus, cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes, and ovaries. The results showed that there were 11 lymph nodes, with no tumor present. However, in the left pelvic lymph nodes, one out of six lymph nodes showed metastatic adenocarcinoma, with no tumor seen in the right periaortic and left periaortic lymph nodes. The uterus was diagnosed with mixed adenocarcinoma, predominantly with serous and endometrioid types with an architectural grade of 3 and nuclear grade of 3. The extent of invasion showed myometrial invasion with outer half, a depth of 1.3 cm, and wall thickness of 2.2 cm with 59% coverage. Serosal involvement, lower uterine segment involvement, and adnexal involvement were all absent. However, the cervical involvement was present. The cervical/vaginal margin and distance were free of tumor, and focal tumor within the cervix was suspicious for lymphovascular invasion with regional lymph nodes showing one involved out of 28 examined. Immunostain for vascular endothelial marker Factor VIIIRA is being performed to assess for lymphovascular invasion, with additional findings to be issued in an addendum report. Immunohistochemistry for ER and PR is pending, but the tumor is ER negative and PR negative. Lymphovascular invasion was confirmed on the immunostain. AJCC Pathologic stage: pT1b pN1 pMx. FIGO (2008 classification) Stage grouping: IIIC1.

The pathology report describes a left renal mass in a patient with a history of diabetes, obesity, and hypertension. The left kidney was submitted for radical nephrectomy, and two tumor masses were identified. The larger tumor mass, measuring 7.1 cm, was identified as high-grade renal cell carcinoma with extensive tubular and tubulopapillary architecture, favored to be a tumor of distal nephron origin. The smaller tumor mass, measuring 2.6 cm, was identified as clear cell (conventional) type renal cell carcinoma, and invaded through the renal capsule but was confined within Gerota's fascia. No tumor invasions were identified in the renal vein, surgical margins were free of tumor, and no lymph nodes were involved. The adrenal gland and suprahilar lymph nodes were benign. Immunohistochemical stains were positive for CK7, Racemase, c-kit, and CA-IX while negative for 34BE12. The overall pathologic stage was pT3 for the smaller tumor and pT2 for the larger tumor.

The pathology report pertains to a patient diagnosed with Mesothelioma. Lymph node and organ biopsies have been conducted, with no signs of tumors observed in the lymph nodes, diaphragm, and liver. However, the biopsy of the right pleura indicates the presence of EPITHELIOID MALIGNANT MESOTHELIOMA, with a positive malignant mesothelioma diagnosis during the frozen section evaluation. SNOMED codes T-2900 and M-90503 are relevant to the diagnosis.

The pathology report describes a right hemithyroidectomy specimen received for tissue banking. The specimen is intact and consists of a right lobe measuring 5.2 cm x 2.5 cm x 1.8 cm and an isthmus measuring 0.9 cm x 0.3 cm x 0.2 cm with two nodules. The dominant nodule measures 2.0 cm in greatest dimension and is diagnosed as multifocal papillary carcinoma, oncocytic follicular variant with minimal tumor capsular invasion and no lymph-vascular or perineural invasion. The second nodule measures 1.1 cm in greatest dimension and is also diagnosed as papillary carcinoma, follicular variant without lymph node metastasis. There are also additional multiple papillary microcarcinomas each 0.1 cm present. A diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis is also made. The TNM descriptors show the primary tumor as pT1b and regional lymph nodes as pNO, with no distant metastasis. Pathologic staging is not applicable. Grossly, fibrous adhesions and silver nitrate paint are found on the external surfaces. No parathyroid glands or lymph nodes are found. The specimen is submitted for freezing and sectioning.

The pathology report pertains to a patient who underwent a radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer and also had an umbilical hernia. The report includes the following information. The adipose tissue anterior to the prostate and three pelvic lymph nodes (two on the left, one on the right) did not show any malignancy. The umbilical hernia was successfully identified and consists of fibroadipose tissue. The prostate and seminal vesicles weighed 40 grams, measured 5 x 4 x 3 cm, and displayed adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 8/10. The tumor site was bilateral and mostly present in the peripheral zone, with invasion into extraprostatic soft tissue on one side. The extent of tumor involvement was more than 50% of the examined tissue. No carcinoma was seen at any margins, seminal vesicles, or lymph nodes. However, perineural invasion was present. No treatment effect on the carcinoma was identified. The TNM staging was pT3a, pNo, pMX. Additionally, extensive acute and chronic prostatitis were observed.

Diagnosis: Urothelial carcinoma with glandular differentiation arising from the urinary bladder, involving the muscularis propria present in the transurethral resection of tumor (TURB-T) specimen. Histologic grade is high, with no evidence of venous/lymphatic invasion or associated epithelial lesions identified. Staging (AJCC): Primary Tumor - pT2, Lymph Nodes - pNX, Distant Metastasis - Cannot be assessed. Clinical information: Bladder tumor. Specimen received: Bladder tumor with multiple irregular fragments of moderately friable, tan pink to red-gray tissue weighing 6.9 grams in aggregate, submitted in A1-A8 wrapped in formalin. Microscopic evaluation performed by the pathologist.

The pathology report describes three specimens received for examination. In specimen A, a sigmoid colon and rectum are received and show an exophytic mass located 2.3 cm from the distal margin with invasion into the muscularis propria. Thirty-two lymph nodes are identified, six of which contain metastatic adenocarcinoma. Specimens B and C consist of right and left tube and ovaries, respectively, both showing no significant pathological findings. The report concludes with a diagnosis of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in specimen A, with metastatic adenocarcinoma present in six of thirty-two regional lymph nodes.

The report describes specimens obtained from right axilla, right breast, right axillary contents levels, and additional breast tissue. The intraoperative consultation diagnosis confirms positive carcinoma in sentinel lymph node #1 in the right axilla. The gross description summarizes the size, shape, and section details of each specimen. Immunohistochemistry confirms the presence of micrometastatic carcinoma in the sentinel lymph node. The biopsy of the second and third sentinel lymph nodes in the right axilla indicates no tumor. In the right breast mastectomy, moderate differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma is present in the upper outer quadrant measuring 1.2 cm in greatest dimension. The ductal carcinoma is also present at the anterior margin in the upper inner quadrant. The breast tissue excision indicates ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) present at the inked aspect. The axillary contents dissection shows no tumor in 13 lymph nodes. Oncotype DX breast cancer assay results indicate a recurrence score of 16 with a low risk of distant recurrence at 10 years. The summary concludes with the final review and addendum from the pathologists.
